org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Justin Ridgewell: Could you describe the semantics you're thinking of in the cross-realm case?
Justin Ridgewell: Could you describe the semantics you're thinking of in the cross-realm case?

content.body: Justin Ridgewell: Could you describe the semantics you're thinking of in the cross-realm case?
content.formatted_body: Justin Ridgewell: Could you describe the semantics you're thinking of in the cross-realm case?

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: (or if there's some JS implementation, point me to it)
content.body: (or if there's some JS implementation, point me to it)
It would require the polyfill to have access to the other realm

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sure, this is a general thing about polyfills that makes them tend to not be spec-complaint
content.body: Sure, this is a general thing about polyfills that makes them tend to not be spec-complaint

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: What are the semantics that you want Realm-separated `wrap` to have at runtime? I just don't know what you're proposing.
What are the semantics that you want Realm-separated wrap to have at runtime? I just don't know what you're proposing.

content.body: What are the semantics that you want Realm-separated `wrap` to have at runtime? I just don't know what you're proposing.
content.formatted_body: What are the semantics that you want Realm-separated wrap to have at runtime? I just don't know what you're proposing.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: like, would Promise.prototype.then do a Realm-separated `wrap` or a cross-Realm one?
like, would Promise.prototype.then do a Realm-separated wrap or a cross-Realm one?

content.body: like, would Promise.prototype.then do a Realm-separated `wrap` or a cross-Realm one?
content.formatted_body: like, would Promise.prototype.then do a Realm-separated wrap or a cross-Realm one?

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: without Realm separation, each microtask queue item can have a single word added to it, which is "what is the whole group of AsyncContexts to restore during this microtask queue item". If we're being Realm-specific... I don't actually know what this should contain.
content.body: without Realm separation, each microtask queue item can have a single word added to it, which is "what is the whole group of AsyncContexts to restore during this microtask queue item". If we're being Realm-specific... I don't actually know what this should contain.
I donâ€™t understand how they would be different. It would still be a single pointer to a map.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: OK, but the map would contain only the async contexts that are in the Realm that called `then`?
OK, but the map would contain only the async contexts that are in the Realm that called then?

content.body: OK, but the map would contain only the async contexts that are in the Realm that called `then`?
content.formatted_body: OK, but the map would contain only the async contexts that are in the Realm that called then?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: so, synchronously, you could call `otherRealmContext.get()` and get that value, but it'd be lost when you restore the microtask queue item
so, synchronously, you could call otherRealmContext.get() and get that value, but it'd be lost when you restore the microtask queue item

content.body: so, synchronously, you could call `otherRealmContext.get()` and get that value, but it'd be lost when you restore the microtask queue item
content.formatted_body: so, synchronously, you could call otherRealmContext.get() and get that value, but it'd be lost when you restore the microtask queue item

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: that's the observable difference of being realm-separated
content.body: that's the observable difference of being realm-separated

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: right?
content.body: right?
Isnâ€™t that intrinsic to then? Like which globals and environment is it going to resume with?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: sure but I imagined this being different from that (since synchronously you can `get` multiple Realms' AsyncContext things)
sure but I imagined this being different from that (since synchronously you can get multiple Realms' AsyncContext things)

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: OK, now I understand. And so what is the advantage of these semantics, of partitioning the AsyncContexts in this way?
content.body: OK, now I understand. And so what is the advantage of these semantics, of partitioning the AsyncContexts in this way?

> Having it be per-realm or per-agent isn't important to me, I chose realm because it's easiest to implement in JS, I figured it be easy in C++, and it seems the least objectionable (per the dedent caching semantics)
content.formatted_body: Having it be per-realm or per-agent isn't important to me, I chose realm because it's easiest to implement in JS, I figured it be easy in C++, and it seems the least objectionable (per the dedent caching semantics)

content.body: Thereâ€™s no real benefit to it this way, itâ€™s just easy

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: One thing it consider is that, in some implementations, this data structure gets a bit complex since you might want to scale up to a large number of `.run` calls nested in each other without that being quadratic (so you don't want to have to clone the whole map for each `.run` call). But I'm not sure whether this argues for Realm-partitioned or global (maybe it's the same?)

One thing it consider is that, in some implementations, this data structure gets a bit complex since you might want to scale up to a large number of .run calls nested in each other without that being quadratic (so you don't want to have to clone the whole map for each .run call). But I'm not sure whether this argues for Realm-partitioned or global (maybe it's the same?)

content.body: One thing it consider is that, in some implementations, this data structure gets a bit complex since you might want to scale up to a large number of `.run` calls nested in each other without that being quadratic (so you don't want to have to clone the whole map for each `.run` call). But I'm not sure whether this argues for Realm-partitioned or global (maybe it's the same?)
content.formatted_body: One thing it consider is that, in some implementations, this data structure gets a bit complex since you might want to scale up to a large number of .run calls nested in each other without that being quadratic (so you don't want to have to clone the whole map for each .run call). But I'm not sure whether this argues for Realm-partitioned or global (maybe it's the same?)

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: oh, also, how should we handle AsyncContexts that aren't in any Realm at all because they're implicitly set by other built-in libraries (e.g., web standards)?
content.body: oh, also, how should we handle AsyncContexts that aren't in any Realm at all because they're implicitly set by other built-in libraries (e.g., web standards)?
I think itâ€™s much more likely that youâ€™ll have many snapshots happening than many nested runs happening, so I prioritized zero-copy snapshots

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: yes, snapshots must be extremely cheap, that's for sure
content.body: yes, snapshots must be extremely cheap, that's for sure

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I don't think one thing excludes another. A classic purely functional map (like Clojure has) would work for what I described.
content.body: I don't think one thing excludes another. A classic purely functional map (like Clojure has) would work for what I described.

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: (snapshots are also free there)
content.body: (snapshots are also free there)
Maybe we could add a multi-run behavior where many contexts are set, to avoid N clones of the map?

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: what do you mean?
content.body: what do you mean?

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: oh, a JS-visible API for that?
content.body: oh, a JS-visible API for that?
`AsyncContext.runMultiple([a, val, b, otherVal])`
So `a` and `b` are set without 2 clones
content.formatted_body: So a and b are set without 2 clones

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I don't think this would remove the potential demand for multiple calls of run being more efficient. Also I'm speculating here; I can't think of when it'd make sense to do that very deeply
content.body: I don't think this would remove the potential demand for multiple calls of run being more efficient. Also I'm speculating here; I can't think of when it'd make sense to do that very deeply

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Generally it should be separate pieces of code which ask for different variables (otherwise they should consolidate into one)
content.body: Generally it should be separate pieces of code which ask for different variables (otherwise they should consolidate into one)

> <@littledan:matrix.org> I don't think one thing excludes another. A classic purely functional map (like Clojure has) would work for what I described.

The issue with pure linked list approaches that a snapshot prevents GC of prior values on the chain
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @littledan:matrix.org
I don't think one thing excludes another. A classic purely functional map (like Clojure has) would work for what I described.
The issue with pure linked list approaches that a snapshot prevents GC of prior values on the chain

content.body: Youâ€™ve had to flatten the chain, but maybe that can happen in a GC step

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah, this is why you wouldn't use a linked list but instead a functional map. Will find a link...
content.body: Yeah, this is why you wouldn't use a linked list but instead a functional map. Will find a link...

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: https://clojure.org/reference/data_structures#Maps
content.body: https://clojure.org/reference/data_structures#Maps

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: anyway probably just a JS Map is good enough in practice; I just wouldn't want to rule out using this theoretically more efficient mechanism in case things come up. But I think this would be possible and doesn't relate to the use of Realms.
content.body: anyway probably just a JS Map is good enough in practice; I just wouldn't want to rule out using this theoretically more efficient mechanism in case things come up. But I think this would be possible and doesn't relate to the use of Realms.

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: see Chris Okazaki's classic thesis for an overview of this topic, summary at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purely_functional_data_structure
content.body: see Chris Okazaki's classic thesis for an overview of this topic, summary at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purely_functional_data_structure

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
> <@littledan:matrix.org> oh, also, how should we handle AsyncContexts that aren't in any Realm at all because they're implicitly set by other built-in libraries (e.g., web standards)?

OK, so I want to dig into this part. This is core to my agenda of linking AsyncContext with Yoav Weiss 's work, which is around built-in variables (which I believe should be propagated in the identical way to AsyncContext)
